content: Solomon’s Other Buildings
But Solomon took thirteen years to build his own house; so he finished all his house.

He also built the House of the Forest of Lebanon; its length  one hundred cubits, its width fifty cubits, and its height thirty cubits, with four rows of cedar pillars, and cedar beams on the pillars.
And  paneled with cedar above the beams that  on forty-five pillars, fifteen  a row.
windows  three rows, and window  opposite window  three tiers.
And all the doorways and doorposts  rectangular frames; and window  opposite window  three tiers.
He also made the Hall of Pillars: its length  fifty cubits, and its width thirty cubits; and in front of them  a portico with pillars, and a canopy  in front of them.
Then he made a hall for the throne, the Hall of Judgment, where he might judge; and  paneled with cedar from floor to ceiling.
And the house where he dwelt  another court inside the hall, of like workmanship. Solomon also made a house like this hall for Pharaoh’s daughter, whom he had taken
All these  costly stones cut to size, trimmed with saws, inside and out, from the foundation to the eaves, and also on the outside to the great court.
The foundation  costly stones, large stones, some ten cubits and some eight cubits.
And above  costly stones, hewn to size, and cedar wood.
The great court  enclosed with three rows of hewn stones and a row of cedar beams. So were the inner court of the house of the  and the vestibule of the temple.
Hiram the Craftsman
Now King Solomon sent and brought Huram from Tyre.

He  the son of a widow from the tribe of Naphtali, and his father  a man of Tyre, a bronze worker; he was filled with wisdom and understanding and skill in working with all kinds of bronze work. So he came to King Solomon and did all his work.
The Bronze Pillars for the Temple(I)
And he cast two pillars of bronze, each one eighteen cubits high, and a line of twelve cubits measured the circumference of each.
Then he made two capitals  cast bronze, to set on the tops of the pillars. The height of one capital  five cubits, and the height of the other capital  five cubits.
a lattice network, with wreaths of chainwork, for the capitals which  on top of the pillars: seven chains for one capital and seven for the other capital.
So he made the pillars, and two rows of pomegranates above the network all around to cover the capitals that  on top; and thus he did for the other capital.
The capitals which  on top of the pillars in the hall  in the shape of lilies, four cubits.
The capitals on the two pillars also  above, by the convex surface which  next to the network; and there  two hundred such pomegranates in rows on each of the capitals all around.
Then he set up the pillars by the vestibule of the temple; he set up the pillar on the right and called its name Jachin, and he set up the pillar on the left and called its name Boaz.
The tops of the pillars were in the shape of lilies. So the work of the pillars was finished.
The Sea and the Oxen
And he made the Sea of cast bronze, ten cubits from one brim to the other;  completely round. Its height  five cubits, and a line of thirty cubits measured its circumference.
Below its brim  ornamental buds encircling it all around, ten to a cubit, all the way around the Sea. The ornamental buds  cast in two rows when it was cast.

It stood on twelve oxen: three looking toward the north, three looking toward the west, three looking toward the south, and three looking toward the east; the Sea  upon them, and all their back parts  inward.
It  a handbreadth thick; and its brim was shaped like the brim of a cup,  a lily blossom. It contained two thousand baths.
The Carts and the Lavers
He also made ten carts of bronze; four cubits  the length of each cart, four cubits its width, and three cubits its height.
And this  the design of the carts: They had panels, and the panels  between frames;
on the panels that  between the frames  lions, oxen, and cherubim. And on the frames  a pedestal on top. Below the lions and oxen  wreaths of plaited work.
Every cart had four bronze wheels and axles of bronze, and its four feet had supports. Under the laver  supports of cast  beside each wreath.

Its opening inside the crown at the top  one cubit in diameter; and the opening  round, shaped  a pedestal, one and a half cubits in outside diameter; and also on the opening  engravings, but the panels were square, not round.
Under the panels  the four wheels, and the axles of the wheels  to the cart. The height of a wheel  one and a half cubits.
The workmanship of the wheels  like the workmanship of a chariot wheel; their axle pins, their rims, their spokes, and their hubs  all of cast
And  four supports at the four corners of each cart; its supports  part of the cart itself.
On the top of the cart, at the height of half a cubit,  perfectly round. And on the top of the cart, its flanges and its panels  of the same casting.
On the plates of its flanges and on its panels he engraved cherubim, lions, and palm trees, wherever there was a clear space on each, with wreaths all around.
Thus he made the ten carts. All of them were of the same mold, one measure,  one shape.
Then he made ten lavers of bronze; each laver contained forty baths,  each laver  four cubits. On each of the ten carts  a laver.
And he put five carts on the right side of the house, and five on the left side of the house. He set the Sea on the right side of the house, toward the southeast.
Furnishings of the Temple(Q)
Huram made the lavers and the shovels and the bowls. So Huram finished doing all the work that he was to do for King Solomon  the house of the :
the two pillars, the  bowl-shaped capitals that  on top of the two pillars; the two networks covering the two bowl-shaped capitals which  on top of the pillars;
four hundred pomegranates for the two networks (two rows of pomegranates for each network, to cover the two bowl-shaped capitals that  on top of the pillars);
the ten carts, and ten lavers on the carts;
one Sea, and twelve oxen under the Sea;
the pots, the shovels, and the bowls.All these articles which Huram made for King Solomon  the house of the   burnished bronze.
In the plain of Jordan the king had them cast in clay molds, between Succoth and Zaretan.
And Solomon did not weigh all the articles, because  so many; the weight of the bronze was not determined.
Thus Solomon had all the furnishings made for the house of the : the altar of gold, and the table of gold on which  the showbread;
the lampstands of pure gold, five on the right  and five on the left in front of the inner sanctuary, with the flowers and the lamps and the wick-trimmers of gold;
the basins, the trimmers, the bowls, the ladles, and the censers of pure gold; and the hinges of gold,  for the doors of the inner room (the Most Holy )  for the doors of the main hall of the temple.

So all the work that King Solomon had done for the house of the  was finished; and Solomon brought in the things which his father David had dedicated: the silver and the gold and the furnishings. He put them in the treasuries of the house of the .
